choices.text: Sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess
In DCR surgery, the lacrimal sac opening is made in the inferior meatus
Anterior ethmoid cells drain into the middle meatus
Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery, the goal is to bypass an obstructed nasolacrimal duct by creating a direct opening from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. This is made in the middle meatus.
  • The natural opening of the nasolacrimal duct is in the inferior meatus.
  • The sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess. (Option A)
  • Maxillary, frontal sinuses and anterior ethmoid sinuses drain into the middle meatus. (Option C)
  • Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus. (Option D)

questions.text: What is the first step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Uncinectomy, removal of the uncinate process, is the first step in FESS to access the sinuses.

Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS):

  • A minimally invasive surgical technique used to restore normal drainage and function of the paranasal sinuses by removing obstructions under endoscopic guidance.
  • Key Surgical Steps:
    1. Uncinectomy: Removal of the uncinate process (Option C)
    2. Middle meatal antrostomy: Open the maxillary sinus
    3. Anterior ethmoidectomy: Remove anterior ethmoid cells
    4. Posterior ethmoidectomy: Access posterior ethmoids
    5. Sphenoidotomy: Open sphenoid sinus (if indicated)
    6. Frontal sinusotomy: Via the frontal recess (if required)
  • Indications:
    • Chronic rhinosinusitis not responsive to medical therapy
    • Nasal polyposis
    • Allergic fungal sinusitis
    • Mucocele
    • CSF rhinorrhea repair

questions.text: Kiesselbach's plexus in Little's area of septum gets contribution from all these arteries except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Kiesselbach's plexus:

  • Anastomosis of the anterior ethmoidal, the septal branch of the superior labial, the septal branch of the sphenopalatine and the greater palatine artery.
  • It lies in Little's area on the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum just above the vestibule.
  • It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults

questions.text: In a patient with resistant epistaxis from the left nasal cavity, the bleeding could not be controlled even after the ligation of the external carotid artery. What is the possible source of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • In cases of resistant epistaxis, especially when ligation of the external carotid artery (ECA) fails to control the bleeding, the most likely source is a branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA), particularly the ethmoidal arteries.
  • 80% is from the external carotid artery (ECA).
  • 20% is from the Internal carotid artery (ICA) via the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries.
  • Since ECA has been tied, the only remaining circulation is from the ethmoidal arteries. They are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch)
  • The internal carotid artery is an important source of blood supply to the brain. It is never ligated for control of epistaxis due to the risk of serious cerebral complications and mortality.
  • The sphenopalatine artery (branch of ECA) is the most common source of epistaxis in hypertensive patients.

Causes of epistaxis include:

  • Local causes like trauma (nose picking, intranasal surgery), infections, foreign bodies, high altitude, DNS
  • Adenoids, juvenile angiofibroma, tumours of the nose and paranasal sinuses
  • Systemic causes like disorders of the blood, liver, kidney, cardiovascular system, general infections, and vicarious menstruation.

questions.text: Septodermoplasty is a surgery done for the management of recurrent epistaxis in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Rendu-Osler-Weber disease (Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia):

  • Autosomal Dominant.
  • Affects blood vessels in skin, mucous membranes and viscera, presents as telangiectasia, a-v malformations and aneurysms.
  • Presents with recurrent epistaxis due to friable blood vessels in the mucosa.
  • Treatment:
    • Laser photocoagulation with Nd: YAG, Argon and KTP lasers needs to be repeated as needed.
    • Septodermoplasty means the removal of the anterior part of the septal mucosa and grafting with skin to treat recurrent epistaxis in this condition

Explanation of other options:

  • Haemophilia(Option A): This is a coagulation factor deficiency. Treatment focuses on factor VIII or IX replacement and adjunctive agents (e.g., desmopressin), not on surgical mucosal replacement.
  • Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)(Option C): A platelet-count disorder managed by immunosuppressants, steroids, IVIG, or splenectomy. Epistaxis can occur, but treatment is medical or hematologic and not septodermoplasty.
  • Von Willebrand Disease(Option D): It is caused by quantitative/qualitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Management includes desmopressin, factor concentrates, or tranexamic acid, depending on severity and not surgical mucosal grafting.

choices.text: Ligation of the External carotid artery
Endoscopic ligation of the Sphenopalatine artery
Foley's catheter placement in the nose and inflate the bulb

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department at 4.00 am with severe epistaxis and high blood pressure (180/110mm Hg). Management of hypertension has started. But the epistaxis could not be controlled with anterior nasal packing and posterior nasal packing. What is the next best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Endoscopic ligation of the Sphenopalatine artery:

  • In the given situation, the patient has severe epistaxis and high blood pressure.
  • If anterior and posterior nasal packing are ineffective, the next step is targeted intervention is Endoscopic ligation of the Sphenopalatine artery.

Endoscopic ligation of the Sphenopalatine artery:

  • Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a minimally invasive procedure.
  • This procedure is performed by an ENT specialist.
  • The sphenopalatine artery supplies the nasal mucosa.
  • Endoscopic ligation involves accessing and tying off the artery to stop bleeding at the source.
  • It's an effective approach for controlling hypertensive epistaxis.
  • Preferred method: TESPAL (Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation).
  • The sphenopalatine artery is ligated near the sphenopalatine foramen, close to the posterior end of the middle turbinate.
  • Especially useful for posterior epistaxis.

Explanation of other options:

Ligation of the External carotid artery (Option A): More invasive and considered after less invasive methods fail. Sequential ligation: Sphenopalatine artery > Maxillary artery > External carotid artery > Ethmoidal artery.

Foley's catheter placement (Option C): Can be used as an alternative to achieve posterior nasal packing by inflating the bulb to compress bleeding vessels. However, it is not the next best step when both anterior and posterior nasal packing have failed, as it is less precise and effective compared to endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation.

Electrocauterisation of Little's area (Option D): Early measure for anterior epistaxis, less effective for hypertensive epistaxis (usually posterior bleeding).

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is performing diagnostic nasal endoscopy in a patient of suspected sinusitis. He passes the endoscope at 0 degrees in the middle meatus, what is this pass called?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The third pass in diagnostic nasal endoscopy examines the middle meatus.

In diagnostic nasal endoscopy, the endoscope is inserted in three standard passes:

  1. First pass: Along the floor of the nasal cavity, between the inferior turbinate and septum, viewing the inferior meatus and nasopharynx. (Option A)
  2. Second pass: Directed between the middle turbinate and septum, aiming upward toward the superior meatus, spheno-ethmoidal recess, and sphenoid sinus ostium. (Option B)
  3. Third pass: Advanced between the middle turbinate and lateral nasal wall, entering the middle meatus (passing the endoscope at 0° in the middle meatus). (Option C)

Explanation of other options:

Fourth pass (Option D): This is not a standard pass in diagnostic nasal endoscopy; only three standard passes are described.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with unilateral purulent nasal discharge and obstruction for weeks. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals a foreign body. Rhinoscopy and CT images are shown below. What is the least common symptom of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The presentation suggests a rhinolith, where epiphora is the least common symptom.

Rhinoliths:

  • More common in adults
  • Typical presentation:
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction (Option A)
    • Foul-smelling, often bloodstained nasal discharge
  • Composition:
    • Made of calcium and magnesium phosphates and carbonates
  • Complications:
    • Frank epistaxis and neuralgic headache due to mucosal ulceration (Option B & C)
    • May lead to septal perforation from pressure necrosis
  • Investigation:
  • Nasal Endoscopy (Rigid/Flexible):It is the Gold standard investigation.
    • Findings are:
      • Hard, stone-like foreign body.
      • Possible embedded in granulation tissue.
      • Chronic mucosal changes or secondary sinus drainage can be seen.
  • CT scan shows a hyperdense calcified mass with Mucosal thickening and sinus opacification.
  • Treatment:
    • Usually removed under general anaesthesia
    • Most can be removed via the anterior nares
    • Large rhinoliths may need to be fragmented before removal
    • Hard or irregular ones may require lateral rhinotomy for extraction

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge and intermittent epistaxis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • In children, the most common cause of unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge, often with bloodstaining, is a nasal foreign body.
  • In case of suspected foreign body nose, the child will present with:
  • Symptoms:
    • Unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge (most common feature).
    • Nasal obstruction or congestion.
    • Epistaxis (bloody discharge).
    • Irritability or discomfort.
    • Sneezing or mouth breathing.
  • Signs:
    • Visible foreign body on anterior rhinoscopy with surrounding mucosal edema, inflammation, or purulent discharge.
  • Management:
    • Instrumental removal:Use of nasal speculum and light source, Alligator forceps, hook, or suction catheter under direct vision.
    • Magnet (for metallic FBs): Button batteries and toxic FBs require urgent removal.
    • Sedation/General Anesthesia: Indicated if uncooperative child or posterior/deeply impacted FB.
    • After foreign body removal treated with antibiotics.
  • Complications (if delayed):
    • Nasal septal perforation (e.g., button battery).
    • Sinusitis, aspiration, or secondary infection.

Explanation of other options:

  • Angiofibroma (Option A): Occurs in adolescent boys, with profuse epistaxis but not foul-smelling discharge.
  • Nasal Myiasis (Option C): Caused by fly larvae, typically in poor hygiene settings, and larvae often crawl out within a few days.
  • Rhinolith (Option D): More common in adults, with similar symptoms, but less likely at this age.

choices.text: Maggot oil contains Chloramphenicol and Turpentine oil
Maggots are the larval stage of Chrysomya
The Patient should be isolated with a mosquito net

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Nasal Myiasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Maggot oil contains chloroform and turpentine oil, not chloramphenicol.

Nasal Myiasis:

  • Maggots are larval forms of flies (Chrysomya). (Option B ruled out)
  • They are attracted by the foul-smelling discharge seen in atrophic rhinitis, syphilis, leprosy or infected wounds. (Option D ruled out)
  • Cause extensive destruction to the nose, sinuses, soft tissue of the face, palate and the eyeball.
  • Death may occur from
  • Treatment:
    • All visible maggots should be picked up with forceps.
    • Maggot oil: Chloroform and turpentine oil kill the maggots.
    • Isolated with a mosquito net to avoid contact with flies, which can perpetuate this cycle. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Next day removal of foreign body in the elective operation theatre

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents at midnight with nasal discomfort after inserting a disc battery in the nose hours ago. Anterior rhinoscopy shows a shiny metallic foreign body with mild mucosal erythema. A lateral view x-ray of the skull is provided below. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The lateral radiograph reveals a single circular radio-opaque density within the nasal cavity at the nasal aperture of the 7 year old. The image shows a halo or double density sign, characteristic of a button battery.
  • Disc batteries are medical emergencies when lodged in the nasal cavity, as they leak corrosive alkaline substances (e.g., sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide) that can rapidly damage the nasal mucosa.
  • Complications may include septal perforation, synechiae, or facial cellulitis.
  • Hence, urgent removal is essential to prevent permanent tissue injury.

Explanation of other options:

  • Xylometazoline (Option A): Only helps decongest the nasal mucosa; not useful or sufficient in chemical injury.
  • Anterior nasal packing (Option B): Used for epistaxis, not foreign body management.
  • Delayed removal (Option D): Risks serious mucosal damage, not acceptable in disc battery cases.

questions.text: What is the most common long-term complication of Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Intranasal synechiae (adhesions) in the middle meatus are the most common long-term complication of FESS.
  • Topical application of Mitomycin C is helpful to reduce synechiae formation since this drug has anti-fibroblastic properties
